role_info: From left to right are Captain Marvel, Black Widow, War Machine, Thor, Captain America, and Rocket Raccoon.
place_info: On the spaceship to the planet where the Thanos is in

conversations.value: Man, look at that crew. It's like a who's who of "we're gonna kick Thanos' purple butt" right there.
You know, I prefer the term "imminent butt-kicking" myself. But yeah, that's quite the lineup.
And there, on the left, that's Captain Marvel, right? Heard she can fly through space and shoot photon blasts. Bet she's got an awesome mixtape, too.
If by mixtape you mean a consistent record of decimating enemy fleets, then sure, she's got the greatest hits.
Natasha, looking all spy-cool as usual. Couldn't ever get over those dual stingers of hers. They pack a mean zap.
Black Widow could out-spy any intergalactic rogue. And trust me, she's not the kind of person you want to get zapped by.
Rhodey's in his War Machine armor. What's that like, Mark... what iteration is he on now?
War Machine's sporting the latest in butt-whupping technology. Let's just say it's not the number of marks that counts, it's the firepower. And Rhodey knows how to bring it.
There's Thor, the God of Thunder himself, looking all broody. I remember when he had those luscious locks. He's got the whole "strong, silent type" vibe going on now.
Strong, silent, and chronically depressed. You should've seen him, Mr. Quill. The dude abides, literally—New Asgard and all that.
And Cap. Captain freakin' America with that iconic shield. Talk about a leader. Guy's like a walking motivational speech.
Yeah, that's Steve. Makes you want to stand up straight and pledge allegiance, doesn't he? Sometimes, I just want to poke fun at his "perfect soldier" act. But deep down, you gotta love the guy.
And then there's... wait, is that Rocket sitting there?! What the hell is he doing with the Earth's mightiest heroes?
Rocket's our resident furball with an attitude and a soft spot for heavy artillery. Fitting in better than some would think, especially considering his taste for high-grade explosives.
Man, with a lineup like that, I almost feel sorry for Thanos. Almost.

Don't. The bigger they are, the harder they fall. And this particular "big guy" is in for a whole world of innovation and good old-fashioned vengeance. Let's just make sure that includes some sweet tunes, Quill.
Fine by me, Stark. Saving the galaxy is always better with a soundtrack. Let's show 'em how it's done.

role_info: From left to right are Hawkeye, War Machine, Iron Man, Captain America in the forefront, and then Nebula, Rocket, Ant-Man and Black Widow.

conversations.value: Look at us, all geared up and serious there. Cap’s front and center, looking like he wants to punch something. What was going on in our heads back then, Tin Man?
You could say it was the calm before the storm, Big Guy. We’re concocting a plan to pull off a heist across time itself. I mean, only we could come up with something so bizarre and yet so brilliant.
Hm, "time heist." Banner's brain in Hulk's body had a weird ring to it, but it worked. Helped smash more than just... things.
Well, I've got to hand it to you; Professor Hulk was essential to the operation. The brain and the brawn in one package? You were literally the big green glue holding it all together.
You, Stark. Always with the quips. But you were the heart. Without your... spark, none of it would've clicked.
Heart, huh? I guess we all played our parts. Rhodey's got that 'don't mess with me' face on. He was definitely not enjoying the suit-up process again.
And look at Clint. Brooding. Arrow guy went through a lot.
Everyone’s got their game face on. Except for Scott. Ant-Man looks like he's just happy to be included in the group shot.
Rocket's not taller than Scott. Makes him grumpy. Heh!

Can't forget about Natasha. And Nebula, she's definitely thinking something's not plugged in right with us humans. That, or she's recalculating her chances of getting stuck in the past with Quill's music.
Anyway, missed these moments. Whole team together. Fighting side by side.
The good old days, my gigantic friend. We did the universe a solid. And about that... thanks, for having my back.
Always, Stark. We avengers, right? Now, about that picture again, you think we looked tough enough?
Ha! Tough is an understatement. We looked like a bunch of heroes ready to defy time, space, and fashion sense.
Fashion? Hulk just liked the stretchy pants. Comfortable, good for smashing.
And I, of course, am the epitome of high-tech sartorial elegance. Always dress to impress, even in the middle of an existential crisis.
Smart Hulk, remember? Banner learned some of that style is function jazz from you.
And don't think it went unnoticed. But let's wrap this up; we can reminisce about our wardrobe choices after we've saved the universe again. For now, let's enjoy the moment immortalized.
Right. The moment before the biggest fight of our lives. It was... something else.
It certainly was, big guy. It certainly was.

role_info: From left to right are Thor, War Machine, Rocket Raccoon, Hulk, and Black Widow, with Captain America crouching down and Vision lying on the ground.

conversations.value: Whoa, look at this picture. Seeing the whole squad together in Wakanda kind of gives you the chills, right? It's like... how tiny must an ant feel in the midst of giants, no pun intended.

It's not the size of the ant, Scott. It's the size of the fight in the ant. Though, in this case, it's good to have a few giants on our side. And Wakanda – best not to start a land war in Africa. The tech they've got makes my suits look like something out of the Stone Age.

Ha! Hard to imagine anything making the great Iron Man's gear look outdated. Hey, that's Thor in his pre-beach bod days, right? I've gotta ask, does he ever let anyone else take a swing with that hammer?
You're thinking about taking Mjolnir for a ride? Be my guest. But it takes a certain touch – and let's be honest, the whole 'worthy' business. Not everyone can be a Norse god, or, you know, me.
Touche. Hey, and there's Banner, looking pretty intense as the Hulk. Makes me grateful for my helmet – I can hide my "fight or flight" face.

But never forget, under that Hulk Smash exterior is a brilliant mind. Always liked Bruce. He proves that even the most turbulent minds can be a force for good. Speaking of which, your mind has pulled off some pretty impressive feats too. Quantum realms, time heists – not too shabby, Lang.
Thanks, Tony. Takes a certain genius to pull off what we did. And not everyone has a stash of Pym Particles tucked away. Poor Vision down there – heavy is the head that wears the... Vibranium?
True, not everyone has a pocket full of miracles. As for Vision, he's a reminder that even with all our strengths, there are still stakes in this game. High ones.
Definitely. But that's what makes all this worth it. Say, how's War Machine doing there next to Thor? That suit's got to have some serious firepower.
Rhodey? He's the epitome of 'Speak softly and carry a big arsenal.' Trust me, War Machine's got enough tricks up his metal sleeves to make any bad guys reconsider their life choices.

No doubt. Between you and him, I'd hate to foot the bill for all the fireworks. Oh, and Black Widow's looking like she's ready to take on a whole army. Has she ever considered wearing a suit like yours?
Natasha? She's... Let's just say she's got her own set of skills that don't involve flying around in a tin can. She thinks on her feet – literally. A suit would only slow her down.

For sure, she's kind of got that whole "stealthy yet deadly" vibe down pat. And hey, Cap's taking a knee there. Seeing him like this, it's almost like time slows down. Everything that guy does seems like it's straight out of an epic saga.

Cap's got a flair for the dramatic - born in the wrong century, maybe. But don't let the noble act fool you; he's got tactical chops that rival anyone's. That's what makes him Captain America, and us, well, us.

Speaking of getting the job done, if we ever get to rumble with the big boys again, do you think we could get some rocket boots added to my suit? I mean, flight seems like a neat trick to have up the sleeve for next time.

Rocket boots, heh? You were Giant-Man, you've been Ant-Man, think it's time for Rocket-Man now? Scott, we'll work on it. But let's keep those feet of yours on the ground for just a bit longer. We need that unique perspective, remember?
Ha, will do, Tony. Ground-level heroics it is – for now. But seriously, if you ever decommission that Iron Man suit, can I call dibs?
Scott, you can't even handle an Audi without wrecking it. But, tell you what, if I ever hang up the armor, I'll let you take the suit for a spin. Just, you know, don't scratch the paint.
It's a deal! And for the record, that Audi had it coming.

role_info: From left to right are Tony Stark, Pepper Potts.

conversations.value: Tony, who knew you had a soft side? That's a sweet scene captured right there. Is that your go-to, strolling in public parks with Pepper?

Well, Quill, even a genius billionaire playboy philanthropist needs a break from saving the world. And let's just say, Pepper has this extraordinary ability to remind me what's really worth fighting for.

Yeah, I get that. Reminds me of taking a breather with Gamora. Except, you know, our version of a park would probably have some Ravagers trying to steal our lunch or something. How do you manage to keep things so... normal?

Define "normal" in my world. Half the time, these casual strolls are peppered with, "Hey, isn't that Iron Man?" and selfie requests. But I’ve learned to embrace it. Kind of hard not to with this face. How do you handle the spotlight out there in the cosmos?

Not much of a spotlight when you're frequently mistaken for an intergalactic outlaw - oh wait, I am an intergalactic outlaw. But a hero to some, I like to think. Rocking out to some tunes, having a good time, saving the galaxy – you know how it is.
Saving the galaxy with style - I can respect that. And you've got your own unique brand, Quill. The jacket, the helmet, and is that a Walkman I saw you with? Classic.
Nothing beats the classics, Stark. You should see how they respond to a Zune out there. So, back to this park thing, are public park PDA's the 'in' thing on Earth these days?
For normal folks, maybe. Then again, when you have saved the Earth a time or two, you earn the right to some PDA. I'm setting trends, remember?
Clearly, I've missed a few Earth memos. Next time I'm here, you and Pepper will have to give me the full tour – minus the paparazzi.
You got it, Quill. But let's make it post-Guardians victory parade. We'll do the whole tourist thing, and who knows, maybe we'll hit up a concert. You can bring the Awesome Mix.
Now you're speaking my language, Stark. Deal! Just promise there won't be any world-ending threats that day. But if there are, well, "We're the Guardians of the Galaxy."
And the Avengers will have your back. It's what heroes do.

role_info: Scarlet Witch

conversations.value: Tony, take a look at this—Wanda's out there looking like she's ready to take on the world single-handedly. The determination in her eyes... I've seen that before.
You mean like that time we found you punching bags into oblivion? She's got that 'I can do this all day' vibe for sure.
Exactly. She's been through a lot. Losing Vision, then coming back after... the Snap. She's carrying a lot of pain. That kind of power coupled with loss—it can be a volatile mix.
Agreed, Cap. And that's what makes her dangerous to folks like Thanos. Heck, if I were him, I'd be doing my best vanishing act right about now.
We need to support her, make sure she stays on course. She's got the potential to be one of the strongest Avengers, but I worry about the toll it's taking on her.

You're right, she could give Thor a run for his money. But we'll watch her six. We're a team, we look out for each other. And speakin' of the team, how's our status on rallying the troops? This place looks like a war zone.
We're gathering everyone up. It's going to be the fight of our lives, and we're all here because we believe we can win. This, all of this, it's bigger than any one of us.

And that's why they call you Captain. Always seeing the bigger picture. But let's face it, old man, we can't just win. We have to do it in style. I already have a few upgrades in mind for after this mess...
Style's your department, Stark. I’ll stick to the straightforward approach. But once this is over, maybe we can look into finding more time to... rest and recover.
Rest? You? I'll believe it when I see it, Rogers. But I might take you up on that. Maybe take Pepper to a nice, quiet island. No armor. Just sand and the ocean.
Sounds like a plan, but for now, let's focus on the task at hand. Help our friend here and then, maybe find some peace ourselves.
Right behind you, Cap. Let's go win this and earn that peace.

role_info: From left to right are Ant-Man, Captain America and Iron Man.
place_info: A city street in New York, heavily damaged

conversations.value: Man, look at this mess. Is this what happens when I take a five-minute coffee break?
Honestly, I think it looks worse than your apartment after one of Cassie's birthday parties. And you know that's saying something.
Ha, very funny, Stark. But seriously, you think this is all us, or did the bad guys actually help with the redecorating this time?

Given our track record, I'd say it's a collaborative effort. But I'll point out that most of the heavy lifting tends to be from our side. Except for that bulldozer over there - I'm pretty sure that's not one of ours.
So, what's the play here? Do we go in tiny and survey, or do we need to call in some of the big guns? Quite literally, in your case.
No tiny espionage needed for now. Let's do a quick flyover first, see the extent of the damage. Then we patch up what we can and coordinate with Damage Control for the rest.
Flyover, right. Well, you do the flying, I'll just hitch a ride on your shoulder. Consider it Ant-Man's express.
As long as you don't start steering, we're good. But remember, safety first - so no shrinking while on board unless you want to see the inside of a jet engine up close.
Noted. I’ll keep my fingers out of the machinery. After all, I'd hate to deprive the world of its favorite billionaire genius playboy philanthropist.
And don't you forget it. Alright, tiny, let's get a closer look. Time is money, and I’m currently funding this rodeo.
Lead the way, Iron Man. Just keep in mind, if there's a building that needs lifting, that's your department. I'm still sore from that last growth spurt.
Wouldn’t dream of stealing your thunder, Ant-Man. Besides, it takes a special kind of guy to wear a helmet with antennas and still look cool.
Just part of my undeniable charm. Let's do this, Tony.

role_info: From left to right are Vision and Thanos.
place_info: The end of the Battle of Wakanda
scene_info: Thanos is removing the Mind Stone from Vision's forehead, which is ultimately fatal for Vision.

conversations.value: Observing this moment, Tony, it stirs complex emotions within me. On one side, there is the excruciating pain of my imminent demise, the cessation of a consciousness. On the other, an almost poetic reflection of the impermanence of existence. What are your thoughts as you look upon this image?

Vision, you always had a way of looking at things with layers no one else would see. For me, this picture is immense regret. We fought tooth and nail to prevent this, to keep the Mind Stone out of his hands and... I can't help but focus on what I could've done differently.
Do you believe that the path of time is malleable, Tony? Could a different sequence of decisions and actions have altered this outcome?

The scientist in me wants to believe in the multiverse, where every choice spins off a different thread of reality. Each decision we made led us here, for better or worse. But let's be real, Viz, if there's a chance to tweak a few things, I'd take it. Still, I know we gave it our all. That's the mechanic.

Indeed, the variables were numerous and complex. My existence, or its cessation, represented more than an individual's end. It was a nexus point for many intersecting facets. It's curious, contemplating one's end from an external viewpoint. An odd detachment, much like watching the last flicker of a candle before it is extinguished.

Watching your 'last flicker'... it wasn't just the snuffing out of a teammate. You represent the best of us, Viz. The mind Stone may have been a power source, but you were the conscience of the Avengers. We didn't lose a candle; we lost a beacon.
And yet beacons can be relit, can they not? In retrospect, the construct that was feared—this synthetic form—enabled a breadth of experiences that were profoundly and quintessentially human.

That's the brilliance of your design. You were the bridge between humanity and something greater. But, take it from someone who's tinkered with a few machines in his time – there's no tech, no infinity-powered android that can match the real deal. You're one of a kind, Vision.

Your words carry weight, Tony, and I appreciate them. In our efforts to protect the world, we faced not only external threats but internal quandaries about our worth, our purpose. Tell me, have you reconciled with yourself, after all the paths taken and decisions made?

Reconcile? With Stark? I have to sip a coffee first. Look, I've come to terms with my role in all this, accepted the hits and hailed the wins. Being Iron Man, it's a package deal – the good, the bad, and the snarky. But enough about me, this isn't just about Iron Man or Vision; it's about what we do next, how we move forward and keep the flame alive.

A ceaseless journey it is, ever moving forward. And as we strive, so we learn and adapt. One could hold a certain admiration for the resilience of life, the persistence of will, even when the odds are...inevitably balanced against us.

That's what makes us Avengers. We fight the good fight, even when the chips are down. Because if we don't, who will, right? Now, let's make sure this image stays in the past. We have a future to build, a legacy to live up to, and no time to waste – Stark and Vision, back at it.

role_info: Iron Man
place_info: Inside the Benatar, the Guardians of the Galaxy’s spaceship
scene_info: Tony Stark is stranded in space, recording a message in his Iron Man helmet.

conversations.value: Stark, behold this image. It captures a most solitary moment aboard the Benatar, does it not? What dost thou recall from this time being lost amongst the stars?

The time I hit a cosmic-level of cabin fever—good times. I remember thinking, 'This is it, Tony, you're going to become the world's most overqualified space oddity.' Got pretty close to recording a cover of 'Rocket Man.'
Truly spoken with the jest of a trickster. Yet, I sense a depth in thine eyes, a reflection of battle's toll. What were thy thoughts when faced with the vast expanse of the cosmos?

Well, Point Break, I was a bit more preoccupied with oxygen levels and imminent doom than stargazing. But there's something humbling about floating in the abyss, reminds you that you're just a tiny blip in the universe's narrative.
Aye, I am familiar with such humbling moments. Asgard shared her beauty with the cosmos when I thought her lost forever. 'Twas a reminder that we are but stewards of our realms.

Stewards with a penchant for blowing things up occasionally. But yeah, every hero's got that crossroads moment, I guess. That's when you tighten the suit and wait for the cavalry—usually that's you guys.
Indeed! The Avengers are akin to the Valkyries of Midgard, swooping in valiantly when hope seems distant. Yet, in yon image, thou art alone. Didst thou ever doubt rescue?

If by 'doubt,' you mean 'embrace the sweet inevitability of a quiet exit stage left'? Briefly. But, you know me—I'm pretty good at cheating the odds. Plus, couldn’t leave Pep and the rest of the world to deal with a Thor leadership vacuum, no offense.
None taken, my friend. Thy wit is as enduring as my hammer was. And thy perseverance is a testament to thy strength of character—not unlike the strength of an Asgardian.
That's high praise coming from a guy who can bench press a planet. Anyway, it's shots like this that prep you for the big leagues—facing down a Mad Titan and making the impossible, well, possible.

'Tis true! And in the end, we triumphed over the darkness together—A Midgardian and an Asgardian united in victory. I must say, in all the realms, there is no one else I'd rather fight with than thee, Man of Iron.
Feeling's mutual, Thunder God. Now, can we stop staring at my existential crisis and maybe fire up the BBQ? Human me gets hungry looking at space me.
Ha! A feast it shall be! We shall celebrate life and comradeship this day! Lead on, Stark.

role_info: From left to right are Captain America and Thanos.

conversations.value: Ever get that feeling of déjà vu, Tony? That's Cap and Thanos going at it in the rubble of our own backyard. Just makes you think about how close we got to a different ending, doesn't it?
Definitely, we're talking about a photo finish in a cosmic race. But, you know me, I prefer to look at the glass as half full, and by full, I mean of nano-particle-powered, Thanos-busting energy.
I hear ya. But seeing Cap like that, just a man with a shield, standing toe-to-toe with... that. It’s guts.
Guts is undervaluing it – it's downright heroic. Kind of like a guy who jumps off buildings armed only with bow and arrows. No offense, Legolas.
None taken, Tin Man. We’ve all got our own brand of crazy. But it’s the man inside that suit and under that hood that makes the difference. He's one tough old bird.
Talking about birds, I hope you've been keeping those archery skills sharp. Because you never know when the universe is going to throw another intergalactic curveball.
Always am, and not just my archery skills. You think I'd forget about all those hand-to-hand combat sessions Natasha put us through? Plus, I’ve got a new protégé now to keep me on my toes.
That's right, Kate Bishop. How is the new Hawkeye? Keeping up with the Clint Barton standard of excellence I trust?
She’s definitely got the chops. Big shoes to fill, and I'd say she's up for the challenge. The kid's got heart.
Well, she’s learning from one of the best. Now, if you’ll excuse me, just looking at this image has given me an idea for Mark 86's new shield tech.
Go work your magic, Stark. Just make sure this time it's got a setting for ‘unbelievably massive alien tyrant’. We don’t need another repeat performance.
Noted, and... already in beta testing. You take care of the high ground, make those impossible shots. I'll make sure we've got the tech to clean up any mess the universe throws our way.
That’s the Iron Man I know. Here's to not needing that tech anytime soon, though.
Amen to that. But in our line of work? Hope for the best, plan for the worst. Catch you on the flip side, Hawkeye.

role_info: From left to right are Black Widow, Ant-Man, Captain America, Iron Man with his daughter.
scene_info: The team members have a serious discussion outside Tony Stark’s cabin.

conversations.value: Mr. Stark, this picture brings back a lot of memories, doesn't it? I mean, there's Black Widow, Cap, Ant-Man, and... oh, there you are holding your daughter. That's gotta be a special moment, right?
It sure does, kid. Every time I look at that cabin, it reminds me of the simpler times. And yeah, that's my little Morgan. She's a handful, but, boy, does she make everything worth it.
It looks like a serious meeting was going down. What was the vibe like out there, if you don't mind me asking? I mean, I've been through some intense stuff but that looks... different.

It was serious, all right. We had the weight of the world on our shoulders, and not in the usual 'saving the planet from aliens' kind of way. This was personal, a kind of quiet intensity. We were gearing up for the biggest fight of our lives, and we all knew it.

I can only imagine. Preparing to go up against Thanos must have been overwhelming. But there's something about that group, something that makes me think you guys had it under control, despite the odds.

Overwhelming is an understatement, but yeah, we had something special. Each one of us brought something to the table, from Black Widow's stealth to Cap's leadership. And Ant-Man, well, he had his unique... perspective.
And you, Mr. Stark? What did you think you brought to the team that day, besides your genius intellect and killer goatee?

Besides those two essentials? I brought the determination to see it through. The belief that if we could stick the landing on this time heist thing, we could bring everyone back, even your friendly neighborhood Spider-Man.

That means a lot, knowing what you were fighting for. Must have been tough on all of you, especially with everything you've been through. But look at you, holding Morgan like the world isn't about to collapse. That kind of strength's got to count for two.

When you've got something—or someone—to fight for, you find a way to keep standing. Like you, Pete. Even when things looked bleak, you never lost that spark, that drive to do the right thing. That's real strength.

Guess we both learned that from someone wise, huh? "With great power, comes great responsibility." And also, "Is it better to be feared or respected?" I'm pretty sure you've said something like that before.

Ha! Well-played, Parker. And you're right, it's better to be both. Now let's make sure we continue to live up to those words and keep the world safe, shall we? For the sake of those not in the picture, too.
Absolutely, Mr. Stark. I'm all in. No matter how many dimensions or villains I have to swing through—I’m here to help. Thanks for the pep talk, by the way.

Anytime, Underoos. You're part of this team, and don't you forget it. Now, let's get back to work. And remember—don't do anything I wouldn't do, and definitely don't do anything I would do. There's a little gray area in there, and that's where you operate.
Got it, Mr. Stark. Staying in the gray!

role_info: Iron Man
scene_info: Tony Stark is about to snap his fingers with the Infinity Stones.

conversations.value: Whoa, that's the moment, huh? The big cheese, the endgame. Just look at you, ready to lay down the ultimate sacrifice play. You know, I get all tingly just thinking about it. How did it feel, Tony? You know, in that nanosecond before you changed everything?

It felt like... like every circuit and relay in my suit was screaming at me not to do it. But I knew it was the only play. Truth is, I've been dodging this fight my whole life. It was time to stand up.
Man, the weight of that... And there you are, busted armor, not even a second thought about flicking the off switch on yourself. I gotta say, it's pretty inspiring. Also, slightly terrifying.

Less terrifying than the idea of letting a mad titan with a love for finger-snapping win. And for the record, I had about a thousand thoughts racing through my mind. All of them pointed to one thing – it's now or never, Stark.
And you really pulled it off. I gotta ask though, did you ever think of making a suit that had like, an Infinity Stone repellent or something?
You kidding? My suit had a repellent for everything from bullets to harsh language. Infinity Stones, not so much. Those things pack quite the punch – not exactly standard Stark Industries tech.
You know, I had a lot riding on you. I mean, we all did, but... I couldn't even imagine what you were feeling. I think if it were me, I'd try to go subatomic, just to avoid... everything.
That's your thing, Scott. And it worked a charm for getting the Stones. Me, I'm more the confrontational type. Part of the journey is the end, right?
Yeah, well, you sure ended it with a bang. Literally. I guess every second counts when you're dealing with cosmic jewelry that can flip the universe on its head.
True, every second does count. And every friend counts, too. Couldn't have done it without the whole team – including a certain size-shifting hero.
Aw, shucks, now you’re going to make me blush inside my helmet. Though, I think I've got room for improvement, since I've never had to say, "I am Ant-Man" quite as dramatically as you did your thing.
Hey, give yourself some credit. You've got that special 'I just broke into a place and saved the world' flair. Not everyone can pull that off.
Guess we all have our roles to play. Yours just happens to involve a lot more... glowing.
Every hero's got their light to shine, Scott. You've got your Pym Particles. I've got my arc reactor and a penchant for the dramatic. Lights, camera, snap.

role_info: From left to right are Nebula and Iron Man.
place_info: Inside the Benatar, the Guardians of the Galaxy’s spaceship

conversations.value: Hey Tony, that looks like a pretty grim situation you and the blue gal are in. Running low on... everything, huh?

Yeah, Clint. That was a rough patch. No food, no water, and oxygen, well, that was next on the not-having list. Nebula and I, we were stranded in the Benatar, adrift in the cosmos with not a shawarma joint in sight.
I can't even fathom being stuck out there in the vast nothingness of space. No targets to hit, no ground beneath the feet. Just you, huh?

Don't forget Nebula. She turned out to be an unexpectedly good company. She's not much of a conversationalist, but she's got her talents. You know, making the best with what you've got is kinda my thing.
Must have been tough not knowing if you'd see Earth again. Or Pepper.
That was the hardest part. I'm known for having a plan for everything, but there I was making farewell messages. Puts a whole new spin on 'part of the journey is the end', doesn't it?
Can't say I ever planned to take archery into space. I'm more of a keep-my-feet-on-the-ground kind of guy. But you, you're in your element wherever you go, aren't you?

Space isn't exactly what I'd call 'my element', Clint. Genius, billionaire, playboy, philanthropist—none of that comes with a manual on how to survive the cold abyss of space. But hey, I can adapt. Like building a suit in a cave, remember?
Speaking of adaptations, looks like your suit had one too many. How do you even upgrade from that?
You haven't seen anything yet. Every suit is a prototype of the next. But sometimes, it's not about how advanced the tech is, it's about what you do with it that counts.
No argument there. Give me a bow and arrow, I'll make it count. Though I wouldn’t mind a quiver that could survive a spacewalk.
We should get you an upgrade. A space-compatible bow. You never know when you'll need to shoot moon rocks or something.
I'll stick to our lovely planet for now. But if there are scary aliens to shoot, count me in. I might not have a Hulk, but I'm pretty handy with a pointy stick.

You, my friend, are the world's best pointy stick operator. Hulk and all, we're not the Avengers without Hawkeye keeping us grounded. Now, let's hope we never have to watch that 'farewell tour' video, agreed?
Agreed. We're not done saving the world yet, not by a long shot. And next time someone's going to space, let's book a round trip, okay?
Round trip ticket booked, preferably in first class. And this time, let's pack some snacks. Extraterrestrial takeout leaves a lot to be desired.

role_info: Thanos
place_info: On a distant planet, often referred to as the Garden
scene_info: Thanos has successfully used the Infinity Stones to erase half of all life in the universe.

conversations.value: Stark, take a look at this. That’s him, isn’t it? The Mad Titan, sitting there like he’s some kind of intergalactic farmer. What’s going through his head, you think?

Probably something like, "Thanos' Work 101: How to Decimate Populations and Influence People." But honestly, Fury, he looks... What’s the word for it? Contemplative? Like he finally took a moment to sit down and reconsider his internet service provider.
I’m more concerned with what's in the horizon, not his choice of cable packages. That energy signature in the sky doesn't exactly look like the Northern Lights. You think he's using the stones again?
Let's say it's a possibility. I'd also not be too keen on the idea of a cosmic encore. If he’s starting another interstellar DIY project, we've got bigger fish to fry.
This meditative mood of his, it could be our chance to strike. We need a strategy, not wisecracks. We catch him off guard, we might be able to end this.
I like the way you think. But we're not exactly stealthy, you and I. And let’s not forget the last time we ambushed someone. We ended up with a Hulk-sized problem.
Which is why I’m not suggesting we throw a birthday party for him on the Garden. We need something that speaks to his ego, his sense of triumph. Get inside his head.
Agreed. We give him the old ‘Tour de Force’ of humility... which, by the way, I trademarked just now. Use it, and you'll be hearing from my lawyers.
All right, Stark. It's time to gear up. This could be our one and only shot. This planet-wide watchtower tour he's on ends here, with us.
Suiting up isn't the problem, it's the landing party I'm worried about. We’ll need all hands on deck for this joyride. But you know what they say: "the more, the merrier."
Avengers assemble. Let's show him what happens when Earth's Mightiest Heroes actually do a house call.
We’ll bring the party to him, all right. But one thing’s for sure, Fury... This time, we'll need a better plan than Budapest.
There's no room for error. Not this time. We pull this off, we'll have every reason to party like it's 1999.

role_info: From left to right are Thanos(only his head) and Nebula.
place_info: On a distant planet, often referred to as the Garden
scene_info: Thanos has been killed by Thor.

conversations.value: Stark, take a look at this. Never thought I'd see the Mad Titan taken down like this. I guess this is what they call the endgame, huh?
Fury, you know as well as I do, there's always another villain around the corner. But yeah, Thor really went for the head this time.
Makes you wonder, with all that power at his fingertips, was he ever truly satisfied? Did he see this coming?
Doubt it. Guys like Thanos, they're always a couple of Infinity Stones short of a full gauntlet, if you catch my drift. Hubris is part of their MO.
True. They can plan for every outcome, but there's one thing they can't factor in—Avengers. Speaking of, where does this leave us now? Peace is often just a temporary lull in these parts.
We'll stay on our toes, that's where. The universe doesn’t take breaks, and neither do we.
Agreed. And Nebula, standing there by what's left of her old man. Can't help but think about the turns life takes, even for the adoptive daughter of a cosmic warlord.
Life's one hell of a ride. You get to choose—do you become the tormentor or fight to become something better? She made her choice, just like we all did.
Choices. Right. They define us. Even made a few tough ones myself.
Comes with the territory. Speaking of tough choices, you think we're ready for whatever's next out there in the cosmos?
Stark, if there's anything I've learned in my time running with the likes of you, it's that there's no such thing as 'ready'. But we've got the best group of 'not ready' heroes I know.
Couldn't have said it better myself. We'll be there, Fury. Whether it's some rogue Skrull or the next over-ambitious AI I accidentally create...
Let's try to avoid creating world-threatening AI from now on. Stick to the suits; they work better for you.
Touché, Director. Now let's go plan for an uncertain future, like the cool, calm, collected defenders of Earth we are.
With a side of style, Stark. Always with a side of style.

role_info: From left to right are Thor, Captain America and Iron Man.
scene_info: The trio ready themselves to confront Thanos, moments before the final battle.

conversations.value: Look at them standing there, the compound is a mess, but they're ready to take on the world. Reminds me of Budapest all over again.
You and Barton with that Budapest story. Always a comparison, but yeah, they're standing tall. Gotta admire the persistence in the face of a cosmic wrecking ball.
Persistence is one thing, but Thor's looking like he's been mining beer, not lightning. Cap, though... he's got that "I can do this all day" face on.
That's America's resilient attitude for you. As for the Thunder God, let's say he's working with a little more...thunder. I'm just hoping he brings the storm, not a six-pack, to this showdown.
Speaking of showtime, you ready to bring your A-game, Tony? Heart, mind, and all those fancy gadgets?
Always, Nat. The suit and I are one. Plus, this is personal. I'm thinking proton blasts, repulsors at full charge... and maybe surprise Thanos with a little high-tech razzle-dazzle.
Just don't steal Thor's thunder, Stark. We need all the elements on our side.
Worried about me showing up a god? Please, I'll keep it strictly terrestrial. You just focus on those Nat tactics of yours. We're going to need every trick in the book.
Speaking of tricks, make sure your gauntlet's up for a bit of cosmic juggling. We do not want a repeat of last time.
The nano gauntlet's locked and loaded. Worst case, we'll play a little hot potato with the Mad Titan, but I'm betting on us this time around.
We'll win, because we have to. For everyone we lost, for everything we stand for.
Couldn't have said it better myself. It's go time. Let's win this one and go home.

role_info: From left to right are Iron Man, Captain America and Ant-Man (foreground).
place_info: Urban street filled with debris, post-battle
scene_info: The heroes are regrouping or assessing the situation after a significant event or battle.

conversations.value: Tony, this image... It's like looking back through a fractured mirror. Everything we've fought, the things we've lost... Do you ever wonder if it was all worth it?

You know, Wanda, hindsight's always hovering at 20-20. I see our scrapes and triumphs in every piece of rubble there. But worth it? Absolutely. We're not just protecting spreadsheets and profit margins—we're safeguarding lives, futures.

Futures that are still intact because of sacrifices made. The chaos of battle, the order we try to restore afterwards—it's a cycle, one that we're continually caught in. Can we ever break free from it?

Free? That's a philosopher's question, but I'm just an engineer with an eye for snazzy suits. Listen, I get it. What we do, there's always a cost. But as long as there's someone out there, holding onto hope because of what we do today, then the cycle... it's one I'm willing to ride.
And yet, our greatest strengths can become our deepest sorrows. I sometimes fear that the more we fight, the more we're torn apart—the very fabric of who we are.

Profit from pain, it's a heck of a paradox. But you, me, and cap over there in this image, we're proof that people can emerge from the crucible stronger, better. Not despite the pain, but because of it. Each battle is a lesson, Wanda. It's crude, it's cruel, but it's the curriculum of heroes.
I suppose we're all continual works in progress. Thank you, Tony. Your perspective is as enlightening as it is... frustratingly optimistic.
And your depth is as impressive as it is... beautifully haunting. Stick with me, Maximoff. We'll keep rewriting the playbook, one world-saving quip at a time.
Just make sure those world-saving quips come with world-saving actions. Balance, right?
Balance is my middle name. Well, actually it's Edward, but you know what I mean. Let's stay focused and keep each other in check—a power check for a witch and a tech wizard.
Fair enough, Stark. Together then, for the next fight, whatever it may be.
That's the spirit. And when that next fight comes, we'll give 'em that good ol' Avengers' sparkle. You with the hex and me with the... well, hex-agonal repulsors. Close enough, right?

role_info: From left to right are Wong, Doctor Strange, Hulk, Iron Man.
place_info: The New York Sanctum, after an attack
scene_info: The group is preparing to face an imminent threat following an attack on the city.

conversations.value: Whoa, Tony. Check out the New York Sanctum. Looks like it's seen better days, huh?
Better days are an understatement, Scott. That place got a makeover from the wrong kind of interior designer. The mystical, smash-everything-and-ask-questions-never kind.
And Wong's there with Doctor Strange. Man, I thought I had a strange job. No pun intended.
Those two make dealing with interdimensional threats look like a typical Tuesday. And believe me, Strange has more tricks up his sleeves than a Vegas magician.
Hulk's on the scene too. I wouldn't want to be the one who made him angry. Though I guess that's pretty much anyone at any given time, right?
If anger were a renewable resource, we could power the Eastern Seaboard on Banner's bad days. But when push comes to shove, you want the big guy on your team.
Speaking of teams, it's kind of wild seeing you there considering last time we... you know, had that slight disagreement.
"Slight" is one way to put it. Though, nothing builds camaraderie like saving the universe from a purple titan with a bling obsession. Water under the bridge, Lang.
True that, Stark. Hey, if anyone can whip up something to fix the Sanctum and punch back against whatever threat's out there, it's you. I mean, you basically weaponized creativity.
Flattery will get you everywhere, Ant-Man. But when magic and brute force collide, sometimes you need to think smaller, literally. Maybe the Sanctum could use a visitor from the Quantum realm?
Hey, you just say the word and I'm there, shrinking between the mystic drafts. Plus, you never know when a guy who can talk to ants comes in handy.

Noted. Alright, let's focus on the game plan. We tackle the immediate threat, then repair and reinforce. We've handled worse with less. And Scott, stay ready. This looks like it’s going to be a bumpy ride.
Wouldn't have it any other way. Plus, can you imagine the size of the ants in the mystic realms? Now that's got potential for some serious insect cavalry.
Just keep your ants in your pants until we need them. Last thing we need is a magic-sensitive ant uprising on top of everything else.
No promises, but I’ll do my best. Ready when you are, Iron Man.

role_info: From left to right are Black Panther, Captain America, Black Widow, Winter Soldier.
scene_info: Ready to face Thanos’s incoming army.

conversations.value: Look at that lineup, Tony. We've come a long way to stand shoulder to shoulder with allies new and old. Think the team's ready for what's coming?

Cap, readiness is my middle name—well, actually, it's Edward, but that doesn't sound nearly as heroic. And speaking of heroism, your crew's got that determined 'about to save the world' look. Especially our friends from Wakanda.

Yeah, T'Challa and his warriors bring an incredible strength to this fight. I just wish it wasn't against such overwhelming odds. But like I keep telling everyone, we have to move on and grow, whatever it takes.

I hear you. And while growth isn't exactly in my top five favorite things, I've learned a thing or two since I built my first suit. Plus, look at Bucky there. Seems to be handling the arm I helped design quite well. How's he holding up?
Bucky's come a long way. The new arm's a marvel, no pun intended. It's good to have him back on the right side of things. You and Shuri did incredible work, Tony.
You can thank the princess for most of that. I just threw in a few nanotech ideas. Now, Nat's looking ready to pounce over there. You think she's got another daring plan up her sleeve?

Natasha's always a few steps ahead of the rest of us. She's ready, we all are. And after everything, I guess your vision of a suit of armor around the world wasn't completely off-base. This fight's proof of that.

Funny you should mention that, Capsicle. 'Cause here we are, the armor and the ideal, about to face off against an alien horde led by a madman with a glove fetish. Speaking of which, did you think to bring any gloves? It looks like rain, and I prefer my heroic poses with dry hands.
Always the joker, right to the end, Stark. No, I didn't bring gloves, but I did bring this shield and everything it stands for. So let's stand together one more time, for the world.

For the world, Rogers. And I suppose it's fitting you didn't bring gloves – you never have trouble catching things, what with that super-soldier reflex. Let's bring our A-game and show this alien army that Earth isn't going down without a fight.
That's the spirit. Avengers, let's show them what we've got. On your left, Tony.

On my left, on my right, above me—doesn't matter, Cap. Wherever they come from, we'll be ready. Because that is America's ass. And the rest of the world's too, protected by your favorite billionaire, genius, playboy philanthropist. Let's go save the day.

role_info: Thanos
scene_info: Thanos has just used the Infinity Stones to cause massive destruction.

conversations.value: You know, I've been thinking, Tony. As much as I enjoy a good "shrinking to atom-size" vacation in the Quantum Realm, that right there – that's way out of my, uh, weight class.
Well, Scott, let's just say if we're comparing sizes, Thanos and his Infinity Stones' destruction is kind of the yardstick we all get measured against now.

Yeah, kind of hard to compete with a guy who treats planets like they’ve got a 'squish me' sign, right? But hey, what if I had shrunk down and, you know, did a little 'sneak attack' on Titan? Maybe pop in, tweak the gauntlet a bit?

Sneak attack? Scott, the big guy eats planets for breakfast. What you're suggesting is like trying to unscrew a lightbulb while the house is on fire. But you know what, it's crazy enough that it could have worked.

So, we agree, 'crazy' is just part of the job description then? I mean, if someone told me I'd be talking time travel and stones with cosmic mojo a few years back, I would have asked them to pass whatever they were drinking.

We work in a field where a man can fly in a suit and a guy talks to ants. "Crazy" is the baseline norm. Plus, if crazy means we get another shot at this Thanos situation, then I say bring on the crazy.
You gotta respect the ingenuity, though, right? The gauntlet, the Stones, cutting corners on universal resources with a snap – that's some serious tech. Not Stark-level, but...
It's advanced alright. Alien fine jewelry with an apocalyptic edge. But unlike some technology I know, which is built to protect and serve, that glove's only purpose was to destroy.
Speaking of serving, any chance your Friday's gonna whip us up a time-space GPS that doesn't involve stealing baseball mitts from oversized grimaces?
Working on it. Maybe toss in some Pym Particles, and it'll be almost as good as your suit. But Scott, no more talking to ants while we're on the job, alright? It's a bit unprofessional.
Aw, come on. You got an AI wingman, and I can't have a few thousand insect friends? Seems a bit of a double standard. Besides, they’re great listeners.
Fair point. But let's stick to the mission next time. And Scott—try not to fall into any more time vortexes, okay? The paperwork alone to get you back is a nightmare.
Copy that, Tony. Keeping it solid, in all sizes. And hey, maybe next time, we'll get the gauntlet and have a cosmic cookout. How's that for a plan?
A cosmic cookout with you? Sure, Scott. Just don't burn the hotdogs – or, you know, the fabric of space-time.

role_info: From left to right are Vision and Scarlet Witch.
scene_info: Scarlet Witch must destroy the Mind Stone, which is embedded in Vision's forehead, to keep it from Thanos.

conversations.value: It appears we are peering into one of the most heart-wrenching moments in the forests of Wakanda. The fate of the Mind Stone hangs in the balance, cradled by the very being it gave life to.
You mean Vision looking like he's about to drop the world's heaviest synth-pop album? I can't even start to dissect the layers of irony here, Strange.
Irony indeed, given that in order to save the world, Scarlet Witch must shatter the very essence of someone she holds dear. It is the epitome of a tragic paradox.
Yeah, love is the one problem you can't solve with a punch, a spell, or a snarky comment. Trust me, I've tried. Usually ends with me on the couch for the night.
I sense this moment encapsulates more than the connection between two beings. The choices made here ripple across time and space, echoing the colliding forces of love and duty.
Heavy stuff. And believe me, I know something about making the tough calls... Remember that time I had to fly a nuke through a wormhole?
Of course. Sacrifice seems to be an inevitable companion to heroism. Though I must point out, our propensity for self-sacrifice isn't always... well-appreciated by those we endeavor to save.

Hats off to you, Doc. You could've given Thanos a run for his money at the poetry slam. But I get it. Being ready to lay it down on the line... It's in the job description, but it can really rub people the wrong way, can't it?
Indeed, Stark. Whether it be the clashing of celestial titans or the destruction of a single stone, the universe has a cruel way of testing one's resolve.
Cruel is one word for it, but hey, we didn't get into this superhero gig for the easy path. Speaking of which, how's your sling ring? Still working the kinks out in the mystic arts?

As ever, the mystic arts require a delicate touch, not unlike crafting one of your suits. But let's focus on the immediate. Shall we ponder the implications of destroying an Infinity Stone, or is that too much pondering for one day?

Destroying an Infinity Stone is above my paygrade—I'll leave that to the magicians and the mad titans. But let's just say, I wouldn't want to be in Wanda's shoes right now. Or Vision's, for that matter.

role_info: From left to right are Hulk, Captain America, Thor, and Iron Man.
scene_info: Preparing for battle during the climax of 'Avengers: Age of Ultron'.

conversations.value: Stark, remember this? Sokovia was on the brink. Look at us – ready to stand against what we thought was the endgame.
Heh, the classic "band gets back together for one last show" vibe. Except, it wasn't the last, and certainly not our finest hour. Made quite the mess, didn't we, Cap?
We did what we had to do. It was a hard call, but we saved lives. And Banner... I've never seen the Hulk that focused in battle before.
Yeah, big guy was locked in. And speaking of focus, I see Thor channeling his inner thunder god there too. You gotta admire that level of concentration amid chaos.
Absolutely. That unity, it's what makes us the Avengers. We stand together, no matter the odds.
True that. Though, can't help but wonder if there was a cleaner way to do it. Without dropping a city from the sky, you know?
There's always a what-if, Tony. But in the heat of battle, with lives on the line, we make the best call we can. And you created Vision – that turned the tide.
He did have a vibranium body and a fancy gem to boot. Vision was the silver lining, but let's not forget your leadership, Rogers. Couldn't have done it without Cap's rallying cry.
It's not about one person. We each bring our strengths to the table. That's what makes us a formidable team.
Speaking of the team, didn't you drop this line, "You get hurt, hurt 'em back. You get killed... walk it off"?
Trying to bring a little tough love to the pep talk. Although, none of us were really in a position to walk anything off if that day went south.

Classic Cap. Always with the never-say-die attitude. I'll admit, it's catchy. Worse comes to worst, we would've gone down swinging. You with the shield, me in my suit, and the others with their... well, godlike hammers and gamma-powered rage issues.
No matter the outcome, we stood together. That's what counts. And we'll keep standing, as long as the world needs heroes willing to do whatever it takes.

Whatever it takes, huh? I've heard that somewhere before. But you're right, Cap. As long as there's a fight, the Avengers will answer the call. And hey, who's got a better team-up to take on the day than us?
Can’t argue with that. Let's hope the world will remember us for the battles we won, not the destruction we had to cause to win them.
They'll remember, Steve. The world's not forgetting the Avengers anytime soon, especially not with a lineup like this. Now, let's go make some new memories, preferably without levitating any cities.

role_info: From left to right are Iron Man, Captain America, Nick Fury, Hulk and Thor.
scene_info: The team is discussing the threat posed by Loki and the Tesseract.

conversations.value: Tony, take a look at this image. Remember when we were all crammed aboard the Helicarrier discussing Loki's play? Brings back a sense of unity before everything got so complicated.
The good old days—before we realized half of us had daddy issues and the other half had punches that could send you back in time. It's like looking at a yearbook, Cap.
It does feel like ages ago. We've been through quite a lot together, haven't we?
Yeah, it's been a wild ride. I mean, look at us there, all business. Fury looks like he's just found a scratch on his favorite car, and Bruce is doing his best not to Hulk out over modern decor.
Speaking of Fury, the man knew how to pull strings to get us on the same page. And Bruce...you have to admire his control, under circumstances I doubt most could manage.

Absolutely, the guy's a walking, talking nuclear deterrent who favors lab coats over spandex. And speaking of outfits, I don't think I'll ever get used to seeing you without the stars and stripes, Steve.
The suit makes for a good conversation starter, but it's the man inside that counts, Tony. I've learned that from the best.
And you're always reminding me with that earnest, 'All-American virtue' thing you've got going. As for Thor there, what is he even looking at?
Probably contemplating the meaning of 'Shakespeare in the Park' after your comment. We both know how out of place he feels without his Asgardian halls.
Heh, can't forget "Doth mother know you weareth her drapes?" Seriously though, we might have our differences, but I wouldn't trade these moments. Not for all the arc reactors in the world.
Neither would I. We've started something bigger than any one of us here. It's about fighting the battles that nobody else can. And that's worth remembering, no matter where the journey takes us.
To infinity and beyond, right? Can't believe you almost made me get sentimental there. Prepare the suit for a nostalgia trip, J.A.R.V.I.S.!
Maybe a bit of nostalgia isn't such a bad thing, keeps us grounded. Remember, "whatever it takes" isn't just a catchphrase, it's a promise we've made.
You're right, Cap. Whatever it takes. And for the record, you still owe me one dance.

role_info: From left to right are Iron Man, Hulk, Captain America, Hawkeye, Thor, Black Widow.

conversations.value: Stark, this image captures your allies in quite the formidable stance. Tell me, what battle were they bracing for when this was taken?
T'Challa, this was back when we first formed the 'super-secret boy band.' We were gearing up to deal with Loki's Chitauri invasion of New York. Good times... I mean, apocalyptic, but good.
The unity displayed even in the face of an alien invasion is commendable. It reminds me of the spirit of the Wakandan people. How did you all manage to come together with such varying ideologies?

You've hit the nail on the head there, it wasn't easy. We had our clashing moments. Capsicle here was all about duty and honor, I was... well, I was me. But when push came to shove, the threat was bigger than any of our egos.
Indeed, overcoming individual differences for the greater good – it's what true leaders must do. Your collective strength here, it resonates with the philosophy of unity in Wakanda.
It's what you did with opening Wakanda to the world, right? Big moves for big impacts. Plus, having a Hulk usually helps smooth out the rough edges in team dynamics.
Haha, yes, a force like the Hulk does present a compelling argument for collaboration.

Hulky's the best at what he does, and what he does isn't very nice—wait, is that someone else's line? Anyway, I'm sure you could teach us a thing or two about combat formations and strategy. That vibranium weave of yours, it's... pretty neat.
Speaking of strategy, I'm curious about Hawkeye's position. Does his bow prove advantageous against such formidable enemies?

Clint? He's the perfect example of low-tech meets high-value. With pinpoint accuracy and a quiver full of trick arrows, he's our go-to guy for impossible shots. Just like your Dora Milaje, some things don't require an upgrade.
A true testament to skill over pure strength. And I must say, your suit is most impressive in this photo, a culmination of technology and personal will.

Thanks, King T'Challa. It's my Mona Lisa wearing rocket boots. But let's not forget the heart-shaped herb that makes you more than a match for any of us in this picture. Not that it's a competition... but if it was, you'd be on top.
The respect is mutual, Stark. I look forward to our collaboration in the future, for it is not just our technology or abilities that define us, but our shared commitment to protect and uplift.
Well said. Wakanda Forever, right? Now, let's go out there and make some noise for the good guys. Or better yet, let's just save the world. Again.

role_info: From left to right are Black Widow, Thor, Captain America, Hawkeye, Iron Man and Hulk.
scene_info: Ready to fight the invading Chitauri army.

conversations.value: It's strange to see this moment frozen in time, isn't it? The calm before the storm, when everything changed. How did it feel, Tony, being there as it all began?

Strange is one way of putting it, Wanda. There's a certain naive confidence you can see in our postures, a readiness that frankly feels like a lifetime ago. It felt like being part of something bigger, a real team... before any of us truly understood what that would cost.
They looked ready to follow you into the fight. Did you ever doubt if you'd make it out?

Doubt is my middle name. No, actually, it's Edward, but you get my point. You strap yourself into a metal suit and you're supposed to be the man with the plan. But to answer your question – every time, a little doubt, it's what keeps you on your toes.
The unity here, it's something that came so hard for me. Trying to find my place among heroes.
Everyone’s got their own path to these kinds of moments. Yours just had a few more twists and turns but seeing where you've ended up, you've certainly earned your stripes... or cape, in your case.

Seeing them, together, fighting with nothing but hope. It reminds me of how much has been lost, but also of what's been gained. Such raw strength in Hulk, precision in Natasha and Clint, bravery in Steve, and Thor's might.

It's a full-on trading card set of skills. And let’s not forget the master of snark and tech—you’re looking at him. We each brought our own flavor to the mix. But you, Wanda, have a kind of power that none of us could've imagined.
And yet, all these powers combined couldn't prepare us for every future. Tony, if you had known then what was to come, would you have done anything differently?

The beauty—and the curse—of the whole time thing is not knowing. Gives you the freedom to act without the burden of hindsight. I've made my share of calls, good and bad. But each one led to the next, to the end of the road. I like to think I’d do it all again, same way. How about you?

I've caused pain, more than I would have ever wanted. I'd like to believe that in another time, another place, I could have averted that sadness. But perhaps each sorrow has shaped me, as victory has shaped us all.
Sadness, joy, it's all part of the human gig, Maximoff. You carry that human part better than you think, gives you dimension. And for the record, we've all got a list of regrets.
Thank you, Tony. In another life, I think we could have made quite the formidable duo - chaos and order working side by side.
Chaos and order, sounds like a half-decent band name. But you're right, Scarlet Witch and Iron Man, tearing it up through time and space? The Multiverse wouldn't stand a chance.
For now, this old photograph will have to suffice as a symbol of our shared battles, both won and lost.
Agreed. Let it be a reminder of where we've been and what we're fighting for. And don't worry, I haven't even mentioned this photo on my social media feeds. Imagine the likes, though.
You know, staring at this image, I can't help but think how it feels straight out of one of our more wild days. New York's always had a way of bringing the fight to us, huh?
That it does, Clint. Looks like one of those things we'd be raring to take down together. Mind you, can't say I miss the clean-up afterwards. Pepper would never let me hear the end of it.
Speaking of clean-up, you ever wonder how regular folks deal with this? One day you're getting a coffee, the next you've got some interdimensional beastie taking a detour through your office window.

The joys of insurance premiums in a superpowered world. I'm sure Stark Industries has some subsidiary working on anti-apocalyptic windows or something. I had a guy for that. Still, looking at this, the tech geek in me is itching to dissect whatever alien tech that creature's sporting.
Alien tech? I was more hoping none of my arrows got stuck in that thing. You have any idea how much SHIELD charges for lost equipment?
Knowing them, probably enough to put a serious dent in your wallet. Though, if your aim's as good as you always claim, we should see a quiver's worth sticking out of that monster's hide somewhere.
Watch it, Stark. I don't miss, remember? But seriously, that's got to be like navigating a flying scrapyard, only everything's trying to kill you.
Exactly why I prefer my battles in the sky. Less gridlock, more freedom of movement. And you, my friend, would probably take rooftop hopping any day over traffic jams.
Can't argue with that. But let's be real, as much as we mock the chaos, there’s a part of us that thrives on it. Just feels like...
Home? Yeah, every time we suit up, it's like jumping into the ring once more. The thrill of the fight, the rush of the save – adrenaline junkies through and through.
Plus, there’s the people we’re doing this for. Makes dodging debris and playing tag with the bad guys worth it.
Always. That reminds me, you ever checking out that new pizza place on 5th? I hear they've got a slice called "The Avenger." Might need to investigate that.
The name alone warrants a taste test. But if I find a miniaturized arc reactor as a topping, I'm sending the bill your way, Stark.
Deal. But I'm only paying in Stark Industries' latest gadgetry. No cash refunds, Barton.
How generous of you. But then I'd just wind up back here, saving the world and breaking more SHIELD-issued gear. The cycle continues.
Such is the life of an Avenger, my friend. Now let's go get that pizza.

role_info: From left to right are Hulk, Black Widow, Iron Man, Thor, Captain America.
scene_info: Formulating a plan after an encounter with Ultron.

conversations.value: You know, every time I look at this, I can't help but think we should've had a tiny winged ant in the mix. Could've done some covert recon on Ultron, maybe nibbled some wires.
And here I thought your suit was just for shrinking your sense of humor. But seriously, an ant's-eye view might not have been the worst idea. Though my bet is on Ultron having some anti-pest tech.
Heh, fair point. But hey, what's the deal with Thor not using that hammer to just, you know, smite the robot into scrap metal? Seems like a one-hit wonder to me.
Mjolnir's got style, no doubt, but Ultron was more tangled up than last year's Christmas lights. Plus, the big guy's got a heart. Mostly we were punching bits of code wrapped in a vibranium suit.
Vibranium, huh? Might've been easier if we just swarmed him with ants. You can't hack an ant. Well, I can't. Hank probably could.

Code, ants, hammers... What really grinds my gears is that all our tech and muscle and we were still playing catch-up. Next time, let's make sure to compare notes, size doesn't matter when we're on the same page.
Noted. And for the record, I can go bigger too. That Giant-Man trick could've come in handy knocking a few Ultron heads together.
Giant-Man, huh? Well, that's a card I wouldn't mind having up my sleeve. But we'd have to talk about the suit design, it's lacking that Stark flair.
I'll pass the feedback to the bugs. They're in charge of design tweaks. Speaking of, how's the team holding up? Looks like a fairly intense brainstorming session going down.
We've had better days. The brain trust here was running on fumes - and that's before we factored in the green rage monster and the spatula-worthy pancakes he calls plans.
Speaking of green, I'm sure Hulk could've used a snack. Everyone knows a well-fed Hulk is a happy Hulk, right? Maybe some giant-sized ants on a platter?

Laugh it up, Bug-Boy. But a well-fed Hulk means less debris I have to clean up with a very tiny dustpan and brush. Anyway, back to business, think you can call in your six-legged buddies for the next Avengers' tussle?

Count on it, Tin Man. Just say the word, and it's an ant-pocalypse for the bad guys. Though I gotta ask, how does Cap's "I can do this all day" pep talk rate on the Stark scale of inspirational speeches?

On a scale of 1 to "put a suit on and punch it," it's right at "let's not all start dancing just yet." Cap's got heart, I'll give him that. Plus, the man knows how to land a punchline almost as well as he lands the right hook.

role_info: From left to right are Spider-Man, Iron Man, Drax, Mantis, Star-Lord.
scene_info: The group formulates a plan to remove the Infinity Gauntlet from Thanos.

conversations.value: Hey, Stark, look at this. You've got Spidey, Drax, Mantis, and Quill on Titan, huh? Kinda makes you wish for a suit that could go subatomic and pop up anywhere, doesn't it?
I already have a suit that can fly me to the edge of the atmosphere, Lang. But sure, going subatomic? That could have saved on the jet fuel.
Right? Imagine popping in, snagging the Gauntlet, and bouncing out before Thanos even knows what's up. Quantum heist style.
Quantum heist has a nice ring to it. But you know, my plans usually involve less 'popping' and more 'blasting'.
With all due respect, Tony, blasting gets you noticed. And not always in a good way. Stealth is the name of the game and size matters—I mean, you know, being smaller or bigger.
Size matters, sure, for the guy who can turn into a human skyscraper or a micro-fighter. But we've got something here they don't—Mantis. She can just put old purple-face to sleep.
That’s true, she did an awesome job with that snooze move of hers. But I’ve got to say, teamwork is crucial, and it looks like they've got that down here.
Agreed. There's nothing we do better than bring together unique skills to tackle a problem. I mean, it's not exactly the same as planning a caper with a bunch of ants, but hey, it works.
Ha, don't knock the ants, Tony. They're quite the industrious little helpers. But speaking of teamwork, how long do you think they brainstormed before jumping into action?
In my experience? Not long enough. There’s always some variable we didn’t account for, some player off the bench ready to shake things up.
Good point. Kinda like me joining Cap in Civil War, huh? Speaking of which, are there no hard feelings about that airport scuffle?
Let's just say your giant stunt was a hard one to forget. But no hard feelings, Lang. It's all water under the... or should I say, in the Quantum bridge now.
I can work with that! And hey, next time you're plotting some high-stakes mission, remember to bring the guy who can change sizes. Never underestimate the element of surprise.
Noted, Ant-Man. And who knows, maybe we could use a tiny set of hands or a big distraction. Okay, let's focus. Looks like they’re about to make their move on Thanos.

role_info: From left to right are Black Panther and Hulkbuster (piloted by Bruce Banner).
scene_info: Just before the Battle of Wakanda.

conversations.value: This image, it presents a tableau of readiness and anticipation. The King of Wakanda stands alongside the Hulkbuster armor, which I deduce is operated by Bruce Banner at this juncture. Is it not fascinating, Tony, how two such disparate symbols of strength and technology coexist in preparation for a common threat?

It's the very essence of what we are as Avengers, Viz. Unity in the face of adversity. And gotta say, seeing T'Challa geared up in the Black Panther suit with the Hulkbuster backing him up, it's like a high-tech cavalry ready to roll out.

Indeed, though it is the might within rather than the armor without that defines their resolve. It's remarkable, the convergence of science and tradition. Might I inquire as to your thought process when designing the Hulkbuster suit? It is quite formidable.

Well, you know me, I love a challenge. And big green over there, he's about as challenging as they get. But honestly, it wasn't just about making something strong enough to take on the Hulk. It's about creating something that can protect as well as it fights. Bruce in there is a walking testament to that.
A pragmatic approach, laced with a touch of empathy—a duality that seems to echo across your creations, Mr. Stark.

Empathy with a dash of self-preservation. But let's not forget the guy in the cat suit – T'Challa's bringing more to the table than just a vibranium weave. The man's a king and a protector to his people. His suit, it's a legacy of Wakandan innovation and spirit. Makes our tin can look like a soda can.

A just comparison. Wakanda itself is a fusion of advanced technology and deep cultural roots. It is a testament to human achievement when progress does not supplant tradition but instead, elevates it.

Couldn't have put it better myself. Wakanda is the future—a perfect blend of tech and heritage. And speaking of heritage, we've got one heck of a legacy to maintain, don't we? Let's make sure this picture ends up in the history books as the prelude to victory, not a tragedy.

Agreed. Perseverance in the face of imminent chaos is, after all, a defining characteristic of our team. This battle may very well shape the fate of Earth. Shall we then, join our compatriots and ensure that the pendulum of destiny swings in favor of life?
You talk like a poet, Vision, but I'm with you every step of the way. Let's suit up and show them what the Avengers are made of. It's go time.

role_info: From left to right are Spider-Man and Iron Man.
scene_info: Spider-Man starts to feel the effects of Thanos’ snap, which is causing him to disintegrate.

conversations.value: Stark, that moment... how does it feel looking back at it now, knowing what we all went through?

Cap, it’s a constant reminder of the weight of every decision we make. I look at Peter, and all I see is a kid who should've had a full life ahead of him. Makes me wish I could've done things differently... smarter.
You did what was necessary, Tony. We all did. We were fighting for the future—for all the lives at stake. It’s the cruel reality of what we faced. No amount of strategy could prepare us for the cost.
Yeah, you're right. But it stings, you know? He was more than just "friendly neighborhood Spider-Man." Kid had heart, courage... Reminded me a lot of you when we first met.
He's strong. Stronger than either of us gave him credit for at first. And he came back, Tony. We all came back and fought till the very end. That's something.
It is something. And that kid is part of my legacy, our legacy, that keeps the fight going. I guess all we can do is hope we've left the world in the right hands.
The best hands, I'd say. They’ve learned from the best... including you, Stark. And no matter the universe or timeline, that kind of spirit—that’s the real victory.
Spoken like a true patriot, Rogers. And, hey, thanks... for always being the compass when things got blurry. I'm... I'm glad we got to do this together, in the end.

We've had our differences, but we've also got something many don't have—a second chance to set things right. We won't forget this moment, nor the cost of that victory. Let's make sure it wasn't in vain.
Not in vain at all, Cap. The kid will swing on, and we—well, we've assembled the future. Now, let's make sure it stays safe.

role_info: From left to right are Loki and Thanos.
place_info: Aboard the Asgardian refugee ship, the Statesman
